title: Why can't the "Enemy Missing" ping be changed visually so it can't be used negatively?
body:
Nobody can deny that the "Enemy Missing" ping gets abused in toxic ways all the time. It happens thousands upon thousands of times every day, where players spam ping their teammates with the question mark ping in a passive aggressive way. This can be enough to set people off sometimes, causing fighting and bad behavior. In order to combat toxicity, we should take away more of the player's ability to be toxic. And at the risk of sounding rude here, anyone who doesn't want the ping to be changed is either abusing it for toxic purposes or simply doesn't like change. These are very bad reasons to keep the ping as it is.

Truth be told while there are many ways to be toxic, making it harder to be toxic will certainly make a difference. There are players who genuinely think "I can't get in trouble if I don't chat, I'll just spam pings instead." Of course while this logic isn't true (Bad actions have consequences and malicious intent is difficult to hide) people still abuse the missing ping and it still causes others to get frustrated, tilted and so on. Believe me, ping spammers have turned matches into a raging wildfire and it'll always happen. Especially due to the power of the passive aggressive question mark. (Side note: Maybe ping spam should be nerfed?)

You might argue that one can simply mute another player's pings, but this isn't a very solid argument: You might miss a valuable ping from that spamming jerk who, at some point, might decide to stop abusing pings. Muting someone in any way, shape or form should always be a last resort due to the fact that muting puts you at a communications disadvantage, which can have game-changing effects if someone you don't want to hear ends up relaying critical information. This is also why players who enter matches and immediately mute everyone can cause lots of frustration, because failing to communicate and cooperate with the team has many consequences.

With all that being said, there is absolutely no good reason not to change the "Enemy Missing" ping to something that can't be weaponized as a tool of toxicity. As for what it should be changed to, unfortunately I don't have any ideas. But I believe that ping spamming, especially abusing the "Enemy Missing" ping makes up a significant portion of toxicity in matches. It's essentially the go-to tool for those moments when players want to be a huge jerk to their team in a subtle way. (Does Riot even see ping spam in chat logs?)

You did this exact same thing in the OP with your "anyone who doesn't want the ping to be changed is either abusing it for toxic purposes or simply doesn't like change" line. 

You are just attempting to disarm people who disagree by putting words in their mouth or insinuating negative things. Funny enough, that's actually a form of passive aggressiveness. 

You also pull the common strategy of leaving yourself an out. You imply that's what I mean then stuck a "I'm sure that's not what you meant" afterwards knowing full well the whole point was to imply that was what I meant. This allows you to imply whatever you want or plant an idea in others' heads while leaving room to deny it later. Another example of this would be saying "no offense but...." in front of something offensive. The primary goal was to say something to offend someone while leaving an out or deniability later.

I'm sorry but a strategy that common rarely works on people who pay attention.

I already addressed the removal of pings in my first post. Pings are far too useful of a tool to just remove when there are better options. It's 2019 and people need to understand that you need to have at least a little thick skin built up when you use the internet. I'm not saying you should have to deal with an essay of verbal abuse directed at you. That is obviously punishable. But if you can't handle an extremely useful tool being misused sometimes when you have the option to just not hear it. Should we remove chat and pings because people misuse them? Of course not.

I think you're taking this way too personal, please calm down. I was simply preemptively countering common and predictable arguments, not trying to personally attack anyone. And why would I have such intentions, if the purpose of this thread was to bring up an issue regarding toxicity while bringing up methods of preventing destructive behavior? I'd like to remind you that you called me "Delusional" which was very rude, and now you're insinuating that I'm resorting to fancy and manipulative tricks? There's no smoke and mirrors here, I simply want to change pings for the better so that they're abused less and have less potential to be used as a weapon of toxicity.

Also, where did I say that I wanted pings removed? The very title of the thread mentions to change the ping visually, not remove pings entirely. I have mentioned multiple times in this thread that there are many creative solutions for making pings less toxic without hindering their usefulness. Finally, using "Just grow thicker skin, it's the internet" is a very poor argument because it shows that you accept things being toxic and negative, rather than being open to fight against it with creative solutions. While thick skin is helpful, it doesn't change the fact that actions should have consequences. Asking everyone to just deal with it and let it happen isn't the answer. Not everyone who points out negativity or injustice is a helpless victim either, I see that things are wrong and I want them corrected. As would anyone who wants something they enjoy to be less negative. You're jumping to conclusions and being very hostile simply because I suggested a small visual change that can help lower toxicity in some areas. There is still an audio cue for pings as well as multiple visual pings because they appear on the chat, map and mini map so changing the question mark to something else isn't going to ruin it's usefulness.

>  I was simply preemptively countering common and predictable arguments

Errrrr no thats not what you did. First of all, you called out ***everyone*** who disagrees regardless of their point and called them either toxic or stubborn in the OP. That is not preemptively addressing a concern. That is a preemptive _**attack**_ on everyone who disagrees. 

Second, you weren't countering a point I made. You implied I made a point that I clearly did not then implied I have a negative mentality for having the stance that you made up for me. This is commonly referred to as a straw man argument. You erect a false or exaggerated point of the other person which you can then easily use to attack their argument or character.

You also imply that it's the actual question mark that makes people upset or angry and not the intent behind it which is just silly. You think that if they changed the question mark to something else it would actually change anything? No lol. It's the intent of the person that starts fights, not a punctuation mark.

The rest of this really just devolves into the classic idealist vs realist argument. I think it's an absurd idea that you will ever rid the internet of assholes. I mean yeah it would be cool if we could do it but it's just never ever going to happen. So in much the same way that you shouldn't have to lock your door because stealing is wrong, you should still lock your door because there are still thieves out there.

No matter what change you make, people will just find new methods to ride the line and get across what they want to get across. As a matter of fact, I have actual proof of this from this very game. Do you know why the punishment system is set up the way it is? Because way back when we didnt have bans for chat in LoL. You just got longer and longer chat restrictions scaling infinitely. What Riot found was that when you removed players' ability to communicate, they often resorted to more serious and harder to detect ways to get their point across like trolling or soft inting. Thats just how it is

I'm deeply sorry that you felt attacked and even frustrated at my goal to find solutions to reduce toxicity. Please, let's be civil and reasonable here. This logic can be comparable to something like saying people who are sick shouldn't receive treatment if their illness doesn't have a cure, because the illness will always be there. Because if enough people did something, then progress would be made, but unfortunately everyone is stuck under the defeatist mindset of "I'm not gonna do anything because nobody else is gonna do anything." Which is painfully ironic. Inaction can have just as much consequence as action. Just because some may have been bred to believe nothing they do matters, doesn't mean that change is impossible.
